title: Russia's economic situation worsens ahead of Donald Trump's return to the White House
summary: Sitting president Vladimir Putin has not responded to the US president-elect's settlement offer. His army remains on the offensive in the Ukraine. However almost three years after the start of the war, signs of a sudden deterioration in the economic situation are multiplying.

title: Las Vegas Tesla explosion: Man in car killed himself before the Cybertruck exploded
summary: In a press statement on the incident, in which a Tesla Cybertruck exploded in front of President-elect Donald Trump's Las Vegas hotel, officials stated that a United States Army soldier in the car had shot himself in the head.

title: Venezuela offers $100,000 reward for exiled opposition's presidential candidate
summary: Venezuelan judicial officials announced that a "wanted" poster for Edmundo Gonzalez Urrutia would be displayed at airports and police checkpoints around the country.

title: Taliban assault on women's rights reaches a new level in Afghanistan
summary: A new directive targeting NGO staffing threatens to stop employing women or face closure, crippling humanitarian operations that rely heavily on female workers to reach vulnerable women in a culture where gender segregation is strictly enforced. Meanwhile, an order to block kitchen windows represents an unprecedented intrusion into private spaces.

title: '2025 will not be the year of democratic recovery'
summary: Despite a few pleasant surprises, the results of elections held around the world have confirmed the erosion of the 'center' and the continuing rise of protest movements, explains Le Monde columnist Alain Frachon.

title: 'Dinosaur highway' tracks dating back 166 million years discovered in England
summary: The discovery, which includes unusual bumps in the quarry's surface, provides rare insight into the movements of prehistoric creatures during the Jurassic period.

title: Apple agrees to $95m settlement in Siri eavesdropping suit
summary: The California-based tech giant has made user privacy a big part of its brand image, and one of the reasons it tightly controls its "ecosystem" of hardware and software.

title: Poland makes 'East Shield' core of its military power ambitions
summary: The country has embarked on a massive reinforcement of its defense infrastructure on the borders with Russia and Belarus. It aims to build Europe's leading army. But the government now in power must face up to the difficult legacy of its predecessors.

title: New Orleans attacker acted solo, no link with Las Vegas Tesla explosion, says FBI
summary: In a press conference, the FBI said that Shamsud-Din Jabbar, the US Army veteran suspected of the deadly truck-ramming attack, had acted alone, aligned with the Islamic State group, and planted homemade bombs.

title: Can Europe buying American oil and gas avert a trade war with Trump?
summary: The president-elect has engaged in a power struggle with Europe, urging it to buy large quantities of American oil and gas. This is a difficult wish to grant, given the low margins available to producers in the US.

title: New Orleans attack: Investigators focus on radicalization of assailant, a US Army vet
summary: The car-ramming attack killed at least 15 people in the crowded streets of the American city during the New Year celebrations. Shamsud-Din Jabbar, 42, born and residing in Texas, left a video in which he pledged allegiance to the Islamic State.

title: With cassava inscribed on UNESCO's World Heritage List, rural Caribbean communities see a 'bright future'
summary: This manioc pancake of pre-Columbian origin is a staple food in the Caribbean and Amazonia. The ancestral know-how required to make cassava has been added to the list of Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity, following the submission of a joint application by five countries in the region.

title: Palestinian Authority suspends Al Jazeera broadcasts
summary: Tensions between the Doha-based network and the Fatah movement of Palestinian President Mahmud Abbas have risen in recent weeks following the channel's coverage of clashes between Palestinian security forces and militants in Jenin.

title: Musk urges release of British far-right figure Tommy Robinson
summary: Elon Musk also renewed his criticism of British Prime Minister Keir Starmer. He has increasingly weighed in on British politics in the last few months.

title: 'Nissan misjudged its vulnerability by unraveling its alliance with Renault'
summary: The Japanese group has been forced to join forces with its compatriot Honda, a marriage that makes little industrial sense. As for the French automaker, it has found itself isolated, fragile and limited in its ability to make the transition to electric vehicles, writes Le Monde columnist Stéphane Lauer.

title: Armed man kills at least 12, including two children, in shooting rampage in Montenegro
summary: The gunman killed the owner of a bar in the city of Cetinje, the bar owner's children and his own family members, authorities said on Wednesday. He later died after shooting himself.

title: In the UK, 'Martha's Rule' aims to allow patients to obtain a second medical opinion
summary: The introduction of this experiment in more than 100 hospitals across the country has saved lives by allowing a review of care or a change of treatment.

title: An exceptional account of Iranian prisons
summary: Columnist Jean-Pierre Filiu notes how Fariba Adelkhah goes beyond a mere prison diary to deliver an anthropology of the prison system in Iran, analyzed from the inside as never before following her detention in Tehran from 2019 to 2023.

title: How 10-minute delivery services are revolutionizing commerce in India
summary: Platforms offering ultra-fast delivery services are booming in the world's most populous country, where they can recruit an almost unlimited workforce. This disruption is destabilizing small, traditional stores.

title: South Korean investigators in standoff to arrest impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol
summary: The suspended president, who issued a bungled declaration on December 3 that shook the vibrant East Asian democracy and briefly lurched it back to the dark days of military rule, now faces arrest, imprisonment, or, at worst, the death penalty.

title: Olga de Amaral, Colombia's textile visionary steps into the light at Paris' Fondation Cartier
summary: Featuring 80 works – most of which have never been shown in France – Amaral's exhibition highlights the earth-shattering energy of the Colombian designer's woven creations.

title: The French far right's slow re-alignment on Ukraine
summary: Jordan Bardella has turned away from the party's prior Russophilia. Yet he maintains a delicate balance between the two positions that coexist among the far right.

title: Dry January more popular than ever, despite lack of government support
summary: The January Challenge, a month-long break from alcohol consumption, offers numerous health benefits. Yet for the sixth consecutive year, the initiative continues without government backing or official policy support in France.

title: Ghana: Fire guts Kantamanto market, heart of Africa's used clothing trade
summary: The fire, which erupted late on Wednesday, January 1, consumed vast sections of the largest used clothes market in the West African country, displacing thousands of traders, disaster officials said.

title: Israeli military allegedly intercepts missile launched from Yemen
summary: Sirens sounded in central and southern Israel on Friday morning as the military said a missile launched from Yemen had crossed into Israeli territory.

title: Luxury brands seek the silver screen
summary: To mark the 60th anniversary of 'Les Parapluies de Cherbourg,' Jacques Demy's masterpiece has benefited from a digital restoration largely supported by Chanel. The fashion house is one of many increasing their support for filmmaking in the hopes of raising their profiles.

title: In the Yarmouk refugee camp, the broken future of Syria's Palestinians
summary: This area on the southern outskirts of Damascus is the beating heart of the Palestinian diaspora. After being reduced to rubble during the civil war, only a few thousand inhabitants still live there.

title: After attack, New Orleans wants to show there is no danger to tourism
summary: The FBI declared that the terrorist, a former US serviceman, had most likely acted alone. Fourteen people were killed and 35 injured.

title: Top European diplomats in Syria for talks with leader Sharaa
summary: French Foreign Minister Jean-Noël Barrot and his German counterpart Annalena Baerbock arrived in Damascus on Friday for discussions on behalf of the European Union.

title: 'The Trump year opens with an anti-democratic, anti-European offensive led by Elon Musk'
summary: Like the US president-elect during his first term, the SpaceX boss attacks European leaders and promotes their opponents on X, his social media network. This is a worrying form of interference in a Europe where the far right is flourishing, writes Le Monde columnist Sylvie Kauffmann.

title: In Warsaw, a feminist clinic lets women speak freely about abortion
summary: Despite campaign promises, the liberal coalition in power has not loosened Poland's strict abortion laws. However, progress is emerging from civil society: An organization has opened a one-of-a-kind health center, where gynecologists and psychologists support women in their decisions, without judgment.

title: French government now aims for public deficit of 5.4% of GDP in 2025
summary: Several tax measures planned for the 2025 budget will not see the light of day, rendering Michel Barnier's 5% deficit target obsolete. To compensate for these missing revenues, a VAT increase has been ruled out.

title: Inmate takes staff hostage at French prison
summary: A prisoner armed with a handmade shank is holding four nurses and one prison guard in the infirmary hostage in the southern city of Arles.

title: Biden rejects Nippon Steel's proposed deal to acquire US Steel
summary: President Joe Biden rejected the nearly $15 billion proposed deal, which he and President-elect Donald Trump had both expressed opposition to.

title: Europe is weaning itself off Russian gas too slowly
summary: Since January 1, Kyiv has halted the transit of Russian gas through Ukraine to Europe without major disruption. But EU member states, which still import gas via the Black Sea's TurkStream pipeline and in the form of LNG, are slow to match their words with deeds.

title: Algeria through Piere Bourdieu's lens, on display at Paris's Pompidou Center
summary: When he was called up to serve in Algeria, in 1955, the sociologist took almost 3,000 photos of the country: Pictures of everyday life, women, men and children, field labor, and much more.

title: French police to face trial over death of man who said he was 'suffocating' durig his arrest
summary: Cedric Chouviat, 42, was tackled to the ground while wearing his motorbike helmet, and was found to have said 'I'm suffocating' nine times during his arrest in January 2020. Judges have found the officers' behavior 'inappropriate, negligent and imprudent.'

title: The KGB's last French secrets in Soviet archives
summary: 'Cold War moles' (Part 1/5). Le Monde is devoting a series of historical investigations to the well-known but partly unexploited archives handed over in 1992 by an exceptional defector, Vasili Mitrokhin. These reveal the little-known extent of Soviet infiltration of France.

title: US House rejects Trump ally Mike Johnson in first speaker vote
summary: With three US House Republicans not backing previous speaker Mike Johnson, the voting will go to another round, despite Johnson beating Democratic minority leader Hakeem Jeffries 216 votes to 215.

title: 'Brothers-in-insomnia': Bernard-Henri Lévy's night-time messages to President Macron
summary: In his new book Nuit blanche ('Sleepless Night'), the philosopher relates his Telegram conversations with another famous insomniac: his neighbor, Emmanuel Macron.

title: Death of Liam Payne: Man arrested in Argentina for supplying drugs to One Direction star
summary: Argentine police arrested one of five men indicted in connection with British singer Liam Payne's death in Buenos Aires, who had allegedly supplied the One Direction member with cocaine, which prosecutors have said he had consumed before falling to his death.
